## Steps to reproduce

```powershell
PS C:\> (Get-Date -Hour 0)

Thursday, 7 January 2021 00:21:15

PS C:\> (Get-Date -Hour 0).Hour
0
PS C:\> (Get-Date -Hour 0).ToString('hh')
12

```

## Expected behavior

`(Get-Date -Hour 0).ToString('hh')` to return the value `0`.

## Actual behavior

`(Get-Date -Hour 0).ToString('hh')` returns the value `12`.

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
hh is 12 hour clock, there is no 0, 12 is midnight and noon.  01 is 1AM and 1PM etc  
HH is 24 hour clock. 00 is midnight, 01 is 1 AM, 12  is noon, 13 is 1pm

H or h will omit the leading zeros.

title: Get-Date return hour as 12 instead of 0 when using .ToString('hh')
